title: Using MySQL in Docker for local testing In Go

inline_content.Text: Id: w4re
Tags: go
PublishedOn: 2017-07-23
HeaderImage: gfx/headers/header-11.jpg
Collection: go-cookbook

title: Description: How and why to run MySQL in Docker when developing Go web apps locally.

inline_content.Text: Description: How and why to run MySQL in Docker when developing Go web apps locally.

title: Imagine you’re writing a web application that uses MySQL. You
deploy on Linux
a
/article/5/blueprint-for-deploying-web-apps-on-coreos.html
but code and test on Mac.

inline_content.Text: Imagine you’re writing a web application that uses MySQL. You
deploy on Linux
but code and test on Mac.

title: What is a good way to setup MySQL database for local developement and testing on Mac?

inline_content.Text: What is a good way to setup MySQL database for local developement and testing on Mac?

title: You can install MySQL on Mac using
official MySQL installer
a
https://dev.mysql.com/downloads/mysql/
or via
Homebrew
a
https://brew.sh/
but my favorite way is to use
docker
a
https://store.docker.com/editions/community/docker-ce-desktop-mac

inline_content.Text: You can install MySQL on Mac using
official MySQL installer
or via
Homebrew
but my favorite way is to use
docker

title: Docker better isolates MySQL from the rest of the system, which has a couple of advantages:

inline_content.Text: Docker better isolates MySQL from the rest of the system, which has a couple of advantages:

title: it’s easier to install the exact version of MySQL that is running in production as there is a docker image for every version

inline_content.Text: it’s easier to install the exact version of MySQL that is running in production as there is a docker image for every version

title: you don’t have to worry that
brew upgrade
c
will upgrade MySQL. Auto-upgrade is desired for most software but not a database. You need to remember to use
brew pin
c
to disable that

inline_content.Text: you don’t have to worry that
brew upgrade
will upgrade MySQL. Auto-upgrade is desired for most software but not a database. You need to remember to use
brew pin
to disable that

title: you can run several different versions of MySQL for different projects

inline_content.Text: you can run several different versions of MySQL for different projects

title: since it’s running on Linux, it’s closer to the code running in production

inline_content.Text: since it’s running on Linux, it’s closer to the code running in production

title: There is a downside to using Docker:

inline_content.Text: There is a downside to using Docker:

title: you have to make sure that the database container is running

inline_content.Text: you have to make sure that the database container is running

title: you need to know the ip address of docker vm running the container

inline_content.Text: you need to know the ip address of docker vm running the container

title: Doing this manually would be annoying and I like to automate so I wrote re-usable bit of Go code to do that.

inline_content.Text: Doing this manually would be annoying and I like to automate so I wrote re-usable bit of Go code to do that.

title: It’s just a matter of running docker commands and parsing their outputs but it’s difficult enough to worth sharing the complete solution.

inline_content.Text: It’s just a matter of running docker commands and parsing their outputs but it’s difficult enough to worth sharing the complete solution.
Conceptually, what we do is:
run
docker ps -a
and parse the output

title: if the container is not running at all, start it with
docker run
c

inline_content.Text: if the container is not running at all, start it with
docker run

title: if the container is stopped, re-start it with
docker start
c

inline_content.Text: if the container is stopped, re-start it with
docker start

title: if the container is already running, extract ip address/port from the output

inline_content.Text: if the container is already running, extract ip address/port from the output

title: MySQL database is stored in a local directory mounted by the container. That way data persists even if the container is stopped.

inline_content.Text: MySQL database is stored in a local directory mounted by the container. That way data persists even if the container is stopped.

title: The code is re-usable. You can customize it by changing:

inline_content.Text: The code is re-usable. You can customize it by changing:

title: the base MySQL container. In my case it’s
mysql:5.6
c
a
https://hub.docker.com/_/mysql/

inline_content.Text: the base MySQL container. In my case it’s
mysql:5.6
where MySQL data is stored

title: name of the container, which should by unique to the project

inline_content.Text: name of the container, which should by unique to the project

title: port on which the database is exposed locally. In the container MySQL listens on standard port 3306. It must be exposed locally on a unique port

inline_content.Text: port on which the database is exposed locally. In the container MySQL listens on standard port 3306. It must be exposed locally on a unique port

title: It can be adapted for other databases, like PostgreSQL.

inline_content.Text: It can be adapted for other databases, like PostgreSQL.

title: We should only start docker when running locally. In my software I use cmd-line flag
-production
c
to distinguish between running in production and locally.

inline_content.Text: We should only start docker when running locally. In my software I use cmd-line flag
-production
to distinguish between running in production and locally.

title: In production I would use the hard-coded host/ip of MySQL server. Locally I would call
startLocalDockerDbMust()
c
go get them.

inline_content.Text: In production I would use the hard-coded host/ip of MySQL server. Locally I would call
startLocalDockerDbMust()
go get them.
